awd_titl_txt: CS for All Teachers: Connect, Cultivate, and Challenge in Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The American Institutes for Research in the Behavioral Sciences (AIR) proposes to enrich and deepen its support for computer science (CS) preK-12 teachers with its CS for All Teachers virtual community of practice (vCoP) that provides assistance to 5,800+ members through a resource collection, discussion groups, webinars, and other supports. 

With this funding, AIR will continue to maintain the vCoP, and develop its functionality around (i) Connecting novice computer science teachers with the resources and people they need to learn rudimentary CS knowledge and skills, (ii) Cultivating a deeper sense of learning for intermediate computer science teachers to improve their teaching practice, and (iii) Challenging veteran computer science teachers to enhance their leadership skills to support their colleagues and advocate for computer science education. In addition, the project will conduct social network analysis to improve our understanding of how best to support computer science teachers virtually and provide opportunities for research on online communities for CS teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_name: American Institutes for Research in the Behavioral Sciences
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: AMERICAN INSTITUTES FOR RESEARCH IN THE BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
As the Computer Science (CS) for All initiative has built momentum and spread across the country, it has brought much-needed attention to CS. To achieve the initiative's goal of CS instruction for students at all grade levels, prekindergarten through Grade 12 (PK-12) teachers will need strong systems of support to ensure that they have the knowledge and skills necessary to teach the new basic skills of computer science. CS for All Teachers was a virtual community of practice, welcoming all teachers from PreK through high school who were interested in teaching computer science.

Managed by the American Institutes for Research (AIR), the goals of CS for All Teachers included the following: (Goal 1: Connect novice computer science teachers with the resources and people they need to learn rudimentary CS knowledge and skills; Goal 2: Cultivate a deeper sense of learning for intermediate computer science teachers to improve their teaching practice; Goal 3: Challenge veteran computer science teachers to enhance their leadership skills to support their colleagues and advocate for computer science education; Goal 4: Contribute research to the field about how best to support computer science teachers virtually.) Over the course of funding from 2018-2023, CS for All Teachers accomplished the following high-level outcomes:

  • (Goal 1, 2, 3) CS for All Teachers had over 8403 total community members (including 1,273 in "CS in Elementary" group; 2,116 in the "CS in Middle School" Group; 4,550 in the "Exploring Computer Science Open Group"; and 3,050 members in the "Computer Science Principles Open Group".
  • (Goal 1, 2) The community had gathered 1,417 crowdsourced resources for CS education PK-12.
  • (Goal 3) CS for All Teachers hosted four cohorts of 28 total Community Ambassadors, who facilitated community groups, created or curated instructional resources, hosted webinars, and more in service of supporting PK-12 CS educators.
  • (Goal 1, 2) The website was averages 260 average page views per day.
  • (Goal 1, 2, 3, 4) The CS for All Teachers Twitter account had more than 11,700 followers. The Twitter account acted as a place to connect CS educators nationally with CS education news, opportunities, and resources.
  • (Goal 1, 2, and 4) CS for All Teachers worked with CSTA to transfer more than 300 curated instructional resources to the CSTA virtual community in December 2022.

In service of Goal 4 (how best to support CS teachers virtually), CS for All Teachers generated some high-level findings, including the following:

  • One of our studies found that teachers with more CS teaching experience have higher levels of self-efficacy and are more likely to share resources than teachers with less CS teaching experience. Moreover, teachers who instruct students at higher grade levels (middle and high school) have higher levels of CS teaching self-efficacy than do teachers who instruct lower grade levels (elementary school). These results suggest that communities of practice (CoPs) can help CS teachers expand their professional networks, gain more professional development resources, and increase CS teaching self-efficacy by creating personalized experiences that consider teaching experience and grade levels taught when guiding teachers to relevant content.
  • To understand CS educators' perspectives on implementing equitable CS instruction during the COVID-19 pandemic, the team administered a survey to the CS for All Teachers virtual community of practice (vCOP) in Spring 2021 and examined responses from middle and high school teachers of CS (n = 349). Survey findings suggest that middle and high school teachers of CS perceive that non-CS courses related to college preparation and testing impacted CS learning opportunities and their schools' ability to offer or expand CS learning from 2020-21. Middle and high school teachers of CS also reported that students? access to reliable broadband internet and familiarity with digital learning tools were the top barriers to providing equitable CS learning opportunities during virtual or hybrid instruction.  These findings echo previous studies of K-12 CS education before, during, and after the COVID-19 pandemic which found that varying state and federal policies related to CS education requirements, and inequities in students? access to technology contribute to significant barriers to equitably implementing and expanding K-12 CS instruction.

Last Modified: 08/08/2023
Modified by: Joseph P Wilson

    Joseph P Wilson

por.por_txt_cntn:
As the Computer Science (CS) for All initiative has built momentum and spread across the country, it has brought much-needed attention to CS. To achieve the initiative's goal of CS instruction for students at all grade levels, prekindergarten through Grade 12 (PK-12) teachers will need strong systems of support to ensure that they have the knowledge and skills necessary to teach the new basic skills of computer science. Over the course of funding from 2018-2023, CS for All Teachers accomplished the following high-level outcomes:

(Goal 1, 2, 3) CS for All Teachers had over 8403 total community members (including 1,273 in "CS in Elementary" group; 2,116 in the "CS in Middle School" Group; 4,550 in the "Exploring Computer Science Open Group"; and 3,050 members in the "Computer Science Principles Open Group".
(Goal 1, 2) The community had gathered 1,417 crowdsourced resources for CS education PK-12.
(Goal 3) CS for All Teachers hosted four cohorts of 28 total Community Ambassadors, who facilitated community groups, created or curated instructional resources, hosted webinars, and more in service of supporting PK-12 CS educators.
(Goal 1, 2) The website was averages 260 average page views per day.
(Goal 1, 2, 3, 4) The CS for All Teachers Twitter account had more than 11,700 followers. The Twitter account acted as a place to connect CS educators nationally with CS education news, opportunities, and resources.
(Goal 1, 2, and 4) CS for All Teachers worked with CSTA to transfer more than 300 curated instructional resources to the CSTA virtual community in December 2022.


In service of Goal 4 (how best to support CS teachers virtually), CS for All Teachers generated some high-level findings, including the following:

One of our studies found that teachers with more CS teaching experience have higher levels of self-efficacy and are more likely to share resources than teachers with less CS teaching experience. Moreover, teachers who instruct students at higher grade levels (middle and high school) have higher levels of CS teaching self-efficacy than do teachers who instruct lower grade levels (elementary school). These results suggest that communities of practice (CoPs) can help CS teachers expand their professional networks, gain more professional development resources, and increase CS teaching self-efficacy by creating personalized experiences that consider teaching experience and grade levels taught when guiding teachers to relevant content.
To understand CS educators' perspectives on implementing equitable CS instruction during the COVID-19 pandemic, the team administered a survey to the CS for All Teachers virtual community of practice (vCOP) in Spring 2021 and examined responses from middle and high school teachers of CS (n = 349). Middle and high school teachers of CS also reported that students? access to reliable broadband internet and familiarity with digital learning tools were the top barriers to providing equitable CS learning opportunities during virtual or hybrid instruction.  These findings echo previous studies of K-12 CS education before, during, and after the COVID-19 pandemic which found that varying state and federal policies related to CS education requirements, and inequities in students? access to technology contribute to significant barriers to equitably implementing and expanding K-12 CS instruction.
